text: We will hear arguments in 72-702, Golden State Bottling Company against the Labor Board.
Mr. Chief Justice, thank you and may it please the Court.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the court.
The concluding clause of yours is one that's very much in dispute despite the findings below, we're told they're clearly erroneous, wholly without support in the record.
That is an issue that is up.
So the question you stated is assumes the answer to another issue in this case?
Well, I would agree that both of those issues are here and I'll try to answer them.
That's a very -- isn't that a very odd application of agency law?
We submit that it is not.
Yes, you tell us to the fact he was in negotiations would allow a permissible inference on the part of the board that he imparted this information which to me is quite a big step.
Well, I think as of the time that he became an employee of All American, it could be imputed All American and that took --
Well, we have some cases that we've cited in our brief, but I think that I have to rest on that position but I think that it's reasonable to infer knowledge from the circumstances.
Yes, in view of Schillingâ€™s contact with All American officials prior to the consummation of the sale.
